poem:
**In the Hall**

In Turbine's hollow,
action spills—
Pollock's ghost through hands.
Silent no more,
we become the brush,
the art,
in flurried strokes,
canvas lives—
innermost ripples
speak louder than
gazing eyes.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Oscar Murillo: The Flooded Garden review – my inner Pollock could not be contained Look at me – I’m Jackson Pollock! Doing action painting in the Tate Turbine Hall! I usually dread interactive art. I prefer to look at art silently, passively and, assuming it’s good enough, to absorb its nuances and meanings slowly. Why do some artists insist on making us doers rather than observers? Queuing with my family to enter the oval arena". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
